qas.question: In Byzantine Gaza, Jews were relaxed on what ban?
Where were ancient remains of a synagogue found in 1966?
The mosaic found in 1966 depicts who as the central figure?
What is the central figure doing in the mosaic found in 1966?
When was the mosaic floor constructed?

context: The ban on <a0_0>figurative depiction<a0_0/> was not taken so seriously by the Jews living in Byzantine Gaza. In 1966 remains of a synagogue were found <a1_0>in the ancient harbour area<a1_0/>. Its mosaic floor depicts <a2_0>King David as Orpheus<a2_0/>, identified by his name in Hebrew letters. Near him were lion cubs, a giraffe and a snake listening to him <a3_0>playing a lyre<a3_0/>. A further portion of the floor was divided by medallions formed by vine leaves, each of which contains an animal: a lioness suckling her cub, a giraffe, peacocks, panthers, bears, a zebra and so on. The floor was paved <a4_0>in 508/509<a4_0/>. It is very similar to that of the synagogue at Maon (Menois) and the Christian church at Shellal, suggesting that the same artist most probably worked at all three places.
